The [*slope angle*]{} $\alpha$ of any line in $\mathbb{R}^2$ is the the
line and $x$-axis; in the case that the line is descending, the angle is
negative. We always have that $-90^{\circ}<\alpha\le 90^{\circ}$.

For all non-vertical lines having a slope of $m$, the slope angle is

$$\alpha=\arctan{m},$$

and we also have that

$$m=\tan\alpha.$$

Below are some examples of slope angles of lines that intersect the
$x$-axis.

In some mathematical works, the slope angle of a line in $\mathbb{R}^2$
is defined to be the angle measured from the positive $x$-axis to the
line in the counterclockwise direction. This definition has some
drawbacks because slope angles are then allowed to be obtuse but can no
longer be negative. When this definition is used, the
$\alpha=\arctan{m}$ no longer holds. The convention in PlanetMath is to
use the former definition.
